stimulusHtml: An object of known mass oscillates horizontally on a spring of known spring constant in simple harmonic motion. At a particular instant the object’s kinetic energy KO and the spring’s potential energy US are determined and are both greater than zero, with US greater than KO. Could the object’s distance from equilibrium be equal to the amplitude of oscillation at this instant? What reasoning can be used to support the claim?
choicesHtml: Yes. The total mechanical energy of the object-spring system can be calculated by adding KO and US.
Yes. Most of the system’s total mechanical energy is in the form of potential energy, which is true whenever the object’s distance from equilibrium is a maximum.
No. The system still has kinetic energy that must be completely converted to potential energy when the object’s distance from equilibrium is a maximum.
No. When the kinetic energy is less than half of the system’s total mechanical energy, the object is approaching the equilibrium position.
